ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Learned about 15th century music in France (Bergundy) and courtly music, music forms, temperament and tuning, and more. We also learned about early music from the "New World" (Mexico)-- both indigenous music and spanish music. We covered several specific pieces of music during both of these times.
important concepts in early western music performance, how to play an early instrument
ancient music.

I gained an appreciation for early music, learned how to play and tune the harpsichord since I have a piano background, and I learned different tuning systems. A technique that I learned that applies to modern music is the idea of basso continuo for the piano/harpsichord which begins to harmonize parts by having the left hand with a bass part playing a melody and the right hand playing chords to match it.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Lecture content was interesting, and listening to pieces that we had recorded was fun. It was unfortunate that we could not play music together in person this year.
Felt like there were different levels of experience which made for different levels of engagement

I played recorder for this course and I loved it so much. It is so fun learning a new instrument for a class. Professor is great and super chill. Highly recommend. Maybe could be improved if Grant left us feedback on submitted recordings
great course but difficult to teach on zoom

One of the strengths of the course is the structure of the course which allows my schedule to be more flexible in turning in recordings of different pieces. For example, some weeks I had a lot of work for other classes and was unable to get recordings of the pieces in, but I was allowed to delay it for a week in order to finish other classes' work and not having set due dates really helped me to enjoy the course and appreciate the music as I could practice when I wanted to most of the time. A weakness of the course is its virtual nature. This course would be much better in person in order to see it all come together; however, because of COVID we had to turn in recordings.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: It was nice that Grant was still able to pull out various instruments and play with us / we could sing together, all muted. The class would definitely do better in person though, just by nature of making music together.
glad to do in person lessons
would be better in person.

The flexible recording schedule succeeded for COVID, but the lectures could be improved. The lectures did not provide as much room for engagement as being able to practice on the instrument and could be improved using software such as PollEv or even trying to make the lectures more personal to the music we were playing as for my part sometimes, the lectures did not really apply as much as others.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yeah, may be more so for vocalists than for instrumentalists
Absolutely this is my favorite course at Yale, I took it 5 semesters
yes, Grant is a phenomenal professor.

I would recommend this course to another student who is familiar enough with an instrument to be able to audition for it. It was a fun experience to be able to play an instrument I had never played before and for anyone that has prior experience playing an instrument and even a slight instrument in early music, this would be the course for them. Especially during COVID times where I did not have access to a piano to practice on, being able to play the harpsichord was even more valuable and I recommend it for those with previous instrument experience looking to try something new.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Also went in-person to play on the instruments
in person weekly lessons
zoom class and occasional instrument rehearsals in person.
Live virtual lectures and there were in-person practices on the instruments.

extras.title:
MUSI 240 01
        The Performance of Early Music
